abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Household Survey and
            Policies for Poverty Reduction Project for Iraq had a
            moderately satisfactory outcome, with the performance of the
            Bank being deemed moderately satisfactory, while the
            performance of the grantee was felt to be satisfactory. Of
            the five project development objectives indicators, three
            were achieved, one was partially achieved, and one was not
            achieved. Of the nine intermediate outcome indicators, two
            were not achieved, while the remaining indicators were
            achieved. Significant lessons learned during the course of
            project implementation were: 1) a fragile government working
            in an unstable environment cannot be expected to produce
            results quickly, particularly when public institutions are
            weak; 2) having a Bank executed trust fund paired with a
            recipient executed trust fund proved to be an extremely
            constructive approach which might be replicated elsewhere;
            3) building government capacity to collect data and do
            policy analysis does not necessarily mean there are
            meaningful results in terms of policy reform and poverty
            reduction; and 4) if risks to development outcomes are very
            high, having a long list of mitigation measures should not
            be used to create an illusion that risks no longer exist.
